clinical_guidelines.organization: American Heart Association, American College of Cardiology, Heart Failure Society of America
clinical_guidelines.scope: Comprehensive management of heart failure in adults

key_recommendations.recommendation: ACE inhibitors or ARBs are recommended for all patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) to reduce morbidity and mortality
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Multiple large randomized trials demonstrate consistent benefit

key_recommendations.recommendation: Beta-blockers are recommended for all stable patients with HFrEF to reduce mortality and hospitalization
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Meta-analysis of major trials shows 35% reduction in mortality

key_recommendations.recommendation: SGLT2 inhibitors are reasonable for patients with HFrEF to reduce cardiovascular death and heart failure hospitalization
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Recent trials show benefit regardless of diabetes status

key_recommendations.recommendation: ARNIs are recommended as a replacement for ACE inhibitors or ARBs in ambulatory patients with HFrEF who remain symptomatic despite optimal therapy
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: PARADIGM-HF trial demonstrated 20% reduction in cardiovascular mortality compared to enalapril

key_recommendations.recommendation: Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists are recommended for patients with HFrEF and NYHA class II-IV symptoms to reduce mortality and hospitalization
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: RALES and EMPHASIS-HF trials demonstrated significant mortality benefit

clinical_guidelines.treatment_algorithm: Guideline-directed medical therapy should be initiated and optimized before considering device therapy or advanced heart failure treatments

special_populations.advanced_renal_disease: Consider dose adjustments for renally cleared medications; monitor electrolytes closely
special_populations.advanced_liver_disease: Avoid certain medications that may exacerbate hepatic impairment
special_populations.elderly: Initiate therapies at lower doses and titrate more slowly; consider comorbidities and polypharmacy

clinical_guidelines.guideline_title: American Diabetes Association Standards of Medical Care in Diabetes - 2023
clinical_guidelines.scope: Comprehensive diabetes care including prevention, diagnosis, and management

key_recommendations.recommendation: HbA1c target <7% for most adults with diabetes
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Reduces microvascular complications and long-term macrovascular events

key_recommendations.recommendation: Metformin is the preferred initial pharmacologic agent for type 2 diabetes
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Proven efficacy, safety profile, and cardiovascular benefits

key_recommendations.recommendation: Consider GLP-1 receptor agonists or SGLT2 inhibitors for patients with established cardiovascular disease
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Cardiovascular outcome trials demonstrate reduced MACE

key_recommendations.recommendation: Blood pressure target <130/80 mmHg for most adults with diabetes
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: ACCORD and SPRINT trials demonstrate reduced cardiovascular events

key_recommendations.recommendation: Statin therapy for all patients with diabetes and cardiovascular risk factors
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Multiple trials show significant reduction in ASCVD events

diagnostic_criteria.diabetes: HbA1c ≥6.5% or fasting glucose ≥126 mg/dL or 2-hour glucose ≥200 mg/dL
diagnostic_criteria.gestational_diabetes: One or more values meeting or exceeding fasting 92 mg/dL, 1-hour 180 mg/dL, or 2-hour 153 mg/dL

clinical_guidelines.screening_recommendations: Screen all adults ≥35 years for diabetes/prediabetes every 3 years

complication_monitoring.nephropathy: Annual urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio and estimated GFR

clinical_guidelines.guideline_title: ACC/AHA Guideline on the Primary Prevention of Cardiovascular Disease
clinical_guidelines.organization: American College of Cardiology, American Heart Association
clinical_guidelines.scope: Primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease in adults

key_recommendations.recommendation: Lifestyle modification is the foundation of cardiovascular disease prevention
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Comprehensive evidence supports diet, exercise, and smoking cessation

key_recommendations.recommendation: Statin therapy for adults 40-75 years with LDL-C ≥70 mg/dL and 10-year ASCVD risk ≥7.5%
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Multiple primary prevention trials demonstrate mortality benefit

key_recommendations.recommendation: Consider coronary artery calcium scoring for risk assessment in intermediate-risk patients
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Improves risk stratification and treatment decisions

key_recommendations.recommendation: Aspirin therapy (75-100 mg daily) may be considered for primary prevention in selected adults 40-70 years at higher ASCVD risk but not at increased bleeding risk
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: ARRIVE, ASCEND, and ASPREE trials show selective benefit in specific populations

key_recommendations.recommendation: Routine aspirin therapy is not recommended for primary prevention in adults >70 years or those at increased bleeding risk
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Increased major bleeding without net cardiovascular benefit

clinical_guidelines.risk_assessment: Use Pooled Cohort Equations to estimate 10-year ASCVD risk
clinical_guidelines.treatment_thresholds: Consider statin therapy when 10-year ASCVD risk ≥7.5% in patients 40-75 years

lifestyle_recommendations.diet: Emphasize vegetables, fruits, legumes, nuts, whole grains, and fish; limit saturated fats, sodium, and processed meats
lifestyle_recommendations.physical_activity: At least 150 minutes per week moderate-intensity or 75 minutes per week vigorous-intensity aerobic activity
lifestyle_recommendations.tobacco: Complete avoidance of tobacco products and secondhand smoke exposure

clinical_guidelines.guideline_title: 2023 ESC Guidelines for the management of arterial hypertension
clinical_guidelines.scope: Diagnosis and management of arterial hypertension in adults

key_recommendations.recommendation: Initiate antihypertensive drug therapy in patients with grade 2 or 3 hypertension regardless of cardiovascular risk
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Multiple trials demonstrate consistent cardiovascular risk reduction

key_recommendations.recommendation: Target office BP <140/90 mmHg in most patients, and <130/80 mmHg if tolerated
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: SPRINT trial demonstrated benefit with lower targets in selected patients

key_recommendations.recommendation: Use combination therapy, preferably in a single pill, as initial treatment for most patients
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Achieves better BP control more rapidly than monotherapy

key_recommendations.recommendation: Consider ambulatory blood pressure monitoring for diagnosis and treatment monitoring
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Superior to office measurements for predicting cardiovascular outcomes

clinical_guidelines.treatment_algorithm: Start with ACE inhibitor/ARB + CCB or diuretic; add third drug from other class if needed

special_considerations.chronic_kidney_disease: ACE inhibitors or ARBs preferred; monitor potassium and creatinine
special_considerations.elderly: Consider higher systolic targets (130-139 mmHg) in frail patients

clinical_guidelines.guideline_title: 2023 AHA/ACC/ACCP/ASPC/NLA/PCNA Guideline for the Management of Patients With Chronic Coronary Disease
clinical_guidelines.organization: American Heart Association, American College of Cardiology, American College of Chest Physicians, American Society for Preventive Cardiology, National Lipid Association, Preventive Cardiovascular Nurses Association
clinical_guidelines.scope: Comprehensive management of patients with chronic coronary disease

key_recommendations.recommendation: High-intensity statin therapy should be prescribed for all patients with chronic coronary disease
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Multiple trials demonstrate reduction in major adverse cardiovascular events

key_recommendations.recommendation: Dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and P2Y12 inhibitor for appropriate duration based on ischemic and bleeding risk
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Balance between ischemic protection and bleeding risk must be individualized

key_recommendations.recommendation: Beta-blockers should be used in patients with heart failure or prior myocardial infarction
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Reduces mortality and recurrent events in post-MI patients

key_recommendations.recommendation: Consider long-term low-dose colchicine for secondary prevention in patients without contraindications
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: COLCOT and LoDoCo2 trials demonstrated reduced cardiovascular events

diagnostic_criteria.chronic_coronary_disease: Established coronary artery disease including prior MI, revascularization, or angiographic evidence of ≥50% stenosis

clinical_guidelines.risk_stratification: Assess both ischemic and bleeding risk to guide duration of dual antiplatelet therapy

lifestyle_recommendations.cardiac_rehabilitation: Refer all eligible patients to comprehensive cardiac rehabilitation programs
lifestyle_recommendations.diet: Mediterranean-style diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and healthy fats
lifestyle_recommendations.exercise: Regular physical activity with at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise per week

clinical_guidelines.guideline_title: 2023 Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease (GOLD) Report
clinical_guidelines.organization: Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease
clinical_guidelines.scope: Diagnosis, management, and prevention of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

key_recommendations.recommendation: Spirometry is required for the diagnosis of COPD; post-bronchodilator FEV1/FVC <0.70 confirms persistent airflow limitation
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Standard diagnostic criteria established through consensus and validated in clinical practice

key_recommendations.recommendation: Long-acting bronchodilators are preferred over short-acting bronchodilators for maintenance treatment
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs demonstrate superior symptom control and reduction in exacerbations

key_recommendations.recommendation: Consider inhaled corticosteroids in combination with long-acting bronchodilators for patients with history of exacerbations
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Reduces exacerbation frequency in selected patient populations

key_recommendations.recommendation: Smoking cessation is the most effective intervention to reduce progression of COPD
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Multiple studies demonstrate slowed decline in lung function with smoking cessation

clinical_guidelines.treatment_algorithm: Based on symptom burden and exacerbation history using ABCD assessment tool

non_pharmacologic_management.pulmonary_rehabilitation: Recommended for all patients with moderate to severe COPD
non_pharmacologic_management.vaccination: Annual influenza vaccine and pneumococcal vaccine as recommended
non_pharmacologic_management.oxygen_therapy: Long-term oxygen therapy for patients with severe resting hypoxemia

clinical_guidelines.guideline_title: 2023 American Thyroid Association Guidelines for Thyroid Disease Management
clinical_guidelines.scope: Diagnosis and management of thyroid disorders

key_recommendations.recommendation: Levothyroxine is the treatment of choice for hypothyroidism
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Extensive clinical experience and randomized trials support efficacy and safety

key_recommendations.recommendation: Target TSH level 0.5-2.5 mIU/L for most adults with hypothyroidism
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Observational data suggest patients feel best within this range

key_recommendations.recommendation: Consider combination therapy with liothyronine in patients with persistent symptoms despite normal TSH on levothyroxine
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Mixed evidence from clinical trials; may benefit selected patients

key_recommendations.recommendation: Antithyroid drugs are first-line therapy for Graves' disease
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Methimazole preferred over PTU except in first trimester of pregnancy

diagnostic_criteria.hypothyroidism: Elevated TSH with low free T4
diagnostic_criteria.subclinical_hypothyroidism: Elevated TSH with normal free T4
diagnostic_criteria.hyperthyroidism: Suppressed TSH with elevated free T4 or T3
diagnostic_criteria.subclinical_hyperthyroidism: Suppressed TSH with normal free T4 and T3

clinical_guidelines.screening_recommendations: Screen adults ≥35 years every 5 years; more frequently in high-risk populations

special_populations.pregnancy: TSH targets differ by trimester; require more frequent monitoring
special_populations.elderly: Consider higher TSH targets (4-6 mIU/L) for patients >70-80 years
special_populations.cardiac_disease: Start with low dose levothyroxine and titrate slowly

clinical_guidelines.guideline_title: 2023 American College of Rheumatology Guideline for the Management of Rheumatoid Arthritis

key_recommendations.recommendation: Treat-to-target strategy with goal of remission or low disease activity
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Multiple trials demonstrate improved outcomes with targeted treatment approach

key_recommendations.recommendation: Methotrexate is the preferred initial conventional synthetic DMARD for most patients
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Superior efficacy and safety profile compared to other DMARDs

key_recommendations.recommendation: Consider early addition of biologic DMARDs in patients with poor prognostic factors
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Improved long-term outcomes with early aggressive treatment in high-risk patients

key_recommendations.recommendation: Low-dose glucocorticoids may be used as bridge therapy but should be tapered and discontinued as rapidly as possible
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Balance between rapid symptom control and long-term adverse effects

clinical_guidelines.diagnostic_criteria: Based on 2010 ACR/EULAR classification criteria including joint involvement, serology, acute phase reactants, and symptom duration

monitoring_parameters.disease_activity: Regular assessment using validated tools such as DAS28, CDAI, or SDAI
monitoring_parameters.safety_monitoring: Regular assessment of CBC, liver enzymes, renal function, and tuberculosis screening before biologic therapy

clinical_guidelines.treatment_algorithm: Step-up approach starting with methotrexate, adding or switching to other DMARDs or biologics based on treatment response

clinical_guidelines.guideline_title: 2023 KDIGO Clinical Practice Guideline for the Management of Glomerular Diseases
clinical_guidelines.scope: Diagnosis and management of glomerular diseases

key_recommendations.recommendation: ACE inhibitors or ARBs are first-line therapy for proteinuric glomerular diseases
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Multiple trials demonstrate reduction in proteinuria and slowing of CKD progression

key_recommendations.recommendation: Corticosteroids are indicated for initial treatment of minimal change disease in adults
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: High response rates demonstrated in clinical trials and observational studies

key_recommendations.recommendation: Consider rituximab for frequently relapsing or steroid-dependent minimal change disease
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Small studies suggest efficacy in reducing relapse rates

key_recommendations.recommendation: Mycophenolate mofetil or cyclophosphamide combined with corticosteroids for initial treatment of proliferative lupus nephritis
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Superior to corticosteroids alone in preserving kidney function

clinical_guidelines.diagnostic_criteria: Requires kidney biopsy for definitive diagnosis of most glomerular diseases

treatment_targets.proteinuria: Target urine protein excretion <0.5 g/day for most glomerular diseases
treatment_targets.blood_pressure: Target <130/80 mmHg for patients with proteinuria

clinical_guidelines.monitoring_recommendations: Regular assessment of kidney function, proteinuria, and disease-specific serologic markers

clinical_guidelines.guideline_title: 2023 IDSA Guidelines for the Management of Community-Acquired Pneumonia
clinical_guidelines.scope: Diagnosis and treatment of community-acquired pneumonia in adults

key_recommendations.recommendation: Use clinical prediction rules such as CURB-65 or PSI to determine site of care
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Validated tools that improve appropriate hospitalization decisions

key_recommendations.recommendation: Empiric antibiotic therapy should cover typical and atypical pathogens
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Beta-lactam plus macrolide or respiratory fluoroquinolone monotherapy

key_recommendations.recommendation: Consider procalcitonin testing to guide antibiotic duration
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: May help reduce unnecessary antibiotic exposure

key_recommendations.recommendation: Pneumococcal and influenza vaccination according to current recommendations
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Significantly reduces incidence of CAP and related complications

diagnostic_criteria.clinical: Presence of symptoms (cough, fever, sputum production) plus radiographic evidence of infiltrate
diagnostic_criteria.severity_assessment: CURB-65 criteria: Confusion, Urea >7 mmol/L, Respiratory rate ≥30/min, BP <90/60 mmHg, age ≥65 years

empiric_treatment_regimens.outpatient: Macrolide or doxycycline; alternative: respiratory fluoroquinolone
empiric_treatment_regimens.inpatient: Beta-lactam + macrolide or respiratory fluoroquinolone monotherapy
empiric_treatment_regimens.severe: Beta-lactam + macrolide or beta-lactam + respiratory fluoroquinolone

clinical_guidelines.duration_of_therapy: Minimum 5 days, with extension based on clinical response; typically 7-10 days total

clinical_guidelines.guideline_title: 2023 AASLD Guidelines for the Management of Nonalcoholic Fatty Liver Disease
clinical_guidelines.organization: American Association for the Study of Liver Diseases
clinical_guidelines.scope: Diagnosis and management of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease

key_recommendations.recommendation: Lifestyle modification with weight loss and exercise is first-line therapy for NAFLD
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Weight loss of 5-10% associated with histologic improvement

key_recommendations.recommendation: Consider vitamin E 800 IU daily for non-diabetic patients with biopsy-proven NASH
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: PIVENS trial demonstrated improvement in histology

key_recommendations.recommendation: Consider pioglitazone for patients with biopsy-proven NASH
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Improves liver histology but associated with weight gain

key_recommendations.recommendation: Screen for and manage cardiovascular risk factors in all patients with NAFLD
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of mortality in NAFLD patients

diagnostic_criteria.nafld: Hepatic steatosis by imaging or histology in absence of secondary causes
diagnostic_criteria.nash: NAFLD with histologic evidence of inflammation and hepatocyte injury

clinical_guidelines.screening_recommendations: Consider screening for NAFLD in high-risk populations such as type 2 diabetes and obesity

monitoring_parameters.liver_function: Regular monitoring of liver enzymes and synthetic function
monitoring_parameters.fibrosis_assessment: Non-invasive fibrosis assessment with FIB-4, ELF test, or vibration-controlled transient elastography

clinical_guidelines.guideline_title: 2023 ASCO Guideline for the Management of Cancer-Associated Anemia
clinical_guidelines.scope: Management of anemia in patients with cancer

key_recommendations.recommendation: Evaluate for correctable causes of anemia before initiating treatment
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Iron deficiency, bleeding, nutritional deficiencies, and hemolysis should be addressed

key_recommendations.recommendation: Erythropoiesis-stimulating agents may be considered for chemotherapy-associated anemia when Hb <10 g/dL
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Reduces transfusion requirements but associated with thromboembolic risk

key_recommendations.recommendation: Iron supplementation should be provided to patients with iron deficiency
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Improves hemoglobin response and may reduce ESA requirements

key_recommendations.recommendation: Red blood cell transfusion for symptomatic anemia or Hb <7-8 g/dL
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Balances benefits of improved oxygen delivery with risks of transfusion

diagnostic_criteria.anemia: Hemoglobin <12 g/dL in women, <13 g/dL in men

treatment_targets.esa_therapy: Target hemoglobin 10-12 g/dL; avoid exceeding 12 g/dL
treatment_targets.transfusion: Goal to alleviate symptoms rather than achieve specific hemoglobin target

clinical_guidelines.monitoring_recommendations: Regular monitoring of hemoglobin, iron studies, and assessment for thrombotic events during ESA therapy

clinical_guidelines.guideline_title: 2023 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Revascularization
clinical_guidelines.organization: American College of Cardiology, American Heart Association, Society for Cardiovascular Angiography and Interventions
clinical_guidelines.scope: Appropriate use of coronary revascularization in patients with coronary artery disease

key_recommendations.recommendation: Revascularization to improve survival is recommended for patients with significant left main coronary artery disease
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Multiple trials demonstrate mortality benefit with CABG compared to medical therapy

key_recommendations.recommendation: PCI or CABG is recommended for patients with stable angina who remain symptomatic despite optimal medical therapy
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Improves quality of life and functional status in symptomatic patients

key_recommendations.recommendation: Radial artery access is preferred over femoral access for coronary angiography and PCI
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Reduces bleeding complications and improves patient comfort

key_recommendations.recommendation: PCI is not recommended for non-culprit lesions during STEMI in hemodynamically stable patients
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: No benefit and potential harm shown in multiple randomized trials

indications.stable_cad: Based on symptom burden, medical therapy response, and extent of ischemia
indications.acs: Early invasive strategy for high-risk patients with NSTEMI and STEMI

procedure_selection.cabg: Preferred for complex multivessel disease, diabetes, and left main disease
procedure_selection.pci: Preferred for less complex disease, suitable anatomy, and higher surgical risk

post_procedure_management.antiplatelet_therapy: Dual antiplatelet therapy duration based on stent type, bleeding risk, and clinical presentation
post_procedure_management.risk_factor_modification: Aggressive management of cardiovascular risk factors post-revascularization

clinical_guidelines.guideline_title: 2023 NICE Guideline for the Management of Depression in Adults
clinical_guidelines.organization: National Institute for Health and Care Excellence
clinical_guidelines.scope: Identification, assessment, and management of depression in adults

key_recommendations.recommendation: SSRIs are first-line pharmacologic treatment for moderate to severe depression
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Multiple meta-analyses demonstrate efficacy and generally favorable side effect profile

key_recommendations.recommendation: Cognitive behavioral therapy is recommended as psychological intervention for depression
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Multiple randomized trials demonstrate efficacy comparable to pharmacotherapy

key_recommendations.recommendation: Consider combination therapy with antidepressant medication and psychotherapy for moderate to severe depression
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Superior to either treatment alone in multiple clinical trials

key_recommendations.recommendation: Continue antidepressant treatment for at least 6 months after remission of depressive episode
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Significantly reduces risk of relapse compared to earlier discontinuation

clinical_guidelines.diagnostic_criteria: Based on DSM-5 criteria including depressed mood, anhedonia, and associated symptoms lasting at least 2 weeks

severity_assessment.severe: Substantial difficulty with daily activities; may have psychotic symptoms

clinical_guidelines.treatment_algorithm: Step-care approach with intensity of treatment matched to depression severity
clinical_guidelines.monitoring_recommendations: Assess for treatment response, side effects, and suicidal ideation regularly, especially during initial treatment phase

clinical_guidelines.guideline_title: 2023 ACR Appropriateness Criteria for Imaging of Suspected Pulmonary Embolism
clinical_guidelines.scope: Appropriate imaging for diagnosis of pulmonary embolism

key_recommendations.recommendation: Use clinical prediction rules (Wells score, PERC rule) to determine pre-test probability
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Validated tools that improve diagnostic accuracy and reduce unnecessary imaging

key_recommendations.recommendation: CT pulmonary angiography is the imaging test of choice for most patients with suspected PE
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: High sensitivity and specificity for detection of pulmonary emboli

key_recommendations.recommendation: Consider ventilation-perfusion scanning for patients with contraindications to CT contrast
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Remains a valuable alternative despite lower specificity than CTPA

key_recommendations.recommendation: Do not perform imaging for PE in patients who meet all PERC rule criteria
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Very low probability of PE in PERC-negative patients with low clinical suspicion

clinical_guidelines.diagnostic_algorithm: Clinical assessment → D-dimer if low/intermediate probability → CTPA if positive D-dimer or high probability

special_considerations.pregnancy: Consider lower extremity Doppler or VQ scan to reduce radiation exposure to breast tissue
special_considerations.renal_impairment: Consider VQ scan or non-contrast MR techniques to avoid contrast nephropathy

clinical_guidelines.guideline_title: 2023 American Academy of Neurology Guideline for Migraine Prevention
clinical_guidelines.scope: Preventive treatment of episodic and chronic migraine

key_recommendations.recommendation: Offer preventive therapy for patients with ≥4 migraine days per month or significant disability
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Reduces migraine frequency, severity, and associated disability

key_recommendations.recommendation: Topiramate, divalproex sodium, and beta-blockers are effective for migraine prevention
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Multiple randomized controlled trials demonstrate efficacy

key_recommendations.recommendation: Consider CGRP monoclonal antibodies for patients with inadequate response or tolerance to oral preventives
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Superior efficacy and tolerability but higher cost than traditional oral preventives

key_recommendations.recommendation: Continue preventive treatment for at least 6-8 weeks at target dose before assessing efficacy
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Adequate trial duration necessary to evaluate treatment response

clinical_guidelines.diagnostic_criteria: Based on International Classification of Headache Disorders criteria including recurrent headache attacks with specific features

treatment_goals.prevention: Reduce headache frequency, severity, and acute medication use

medication_selection.first_line: Beta-blockers, topiramate, divalproex sodium based on comorbidities
medication_selection.second_line: CGRP monoclonal antibodies, antidepressants, other antiepileptics
medication_selection.special_populations: Consider pregnancy potential, comorbidities, and drug interactions

clinical_guidelines.guideline_title: 2023 American Gastroenterological Association Guideline on the Management of Irritable Bowel Syndrome
clinical_guidelines.scope: Diagnosis and management of irritable bowel syndrome

key_recommendations.recommendation: Diagnose IBS based on symptom criteria (Rome IV) without extensive testing in absence of alarm features
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Limited diagnostic testing is cost-effective and avoids unnecessary procedures

key_recommendations.recommendation: Recommend a trial of low FODMAP diet for patients with IBS
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Multiple randomized trials demonstrate improvement in global symptoms

key_recommendations.recommendation: Consider peppermint oil for global symptom improvement in IBS
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Meta-analyses show benefit for overall symptoms and abdominal pain

key_recommendations.recommendation: Use psychological therapies (CBT, gut-directed hypnotherapy) for patients with refractory symptoms
key_recommendations.evidence_summary: Effective for reducing symptom severity and improving quality of life

clinical_guidelines.diagnostic_criteria: Rome IV criteria: Recurrent abdominal pain at least 1 day/week associated with change in frequency or form of stool

treatment_approach.dietary: Low FODMAP diet, fiber supplementation based on subtype
treatment_approach.pharmacologic: Antispasmodics, antidepressants, secretagogues, bile acid sequestrants based on subtype
treatment_approach.psychological: Cognitive behavioral therapy, gut-directed hypnotherapy for refractory symptoms
